action.action-desc: Ms. McBride (for herself and Mrs. Kim) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Financial Services

form.official-title: To amend the Credit Repair Organizations Act to add additional protections against harmful practices within the credit repair organization industry, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Ending Scam Credit Repair Act or the ESCRA Act.

subsection.text: Section 404 of the Credit Repair Organizations Act (15 U.S.C. 1679b) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subsection (a)(2)—

subparagraph.text: in subparagraph (B)(ii), by inserting or after credit;; and

paragraph.text: by amending subsection (b) to read as follows:

No credit repair organization may request or receive payment of any fee or consideration from a consumer for services represented to remove derogatory or inaccurate information from, or improve, such consumer's credit history, credit record, or credit rating, or services related to such a representation, until the credit repair organization has provided such consumer with documentation in the form of a consumer report, issued not less than 6 months after such service, from a consumer reporting agency that demonstrates that such representation has been achieved.
Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to alter the permissible purposes of furnishing a consumer report described in section 604 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act.
by adding at the end the following:

subsection.text: A credit repair organization may not submit multiple disputes described in section 611 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act of the same information unless all of the following are true:

paragraph.text: The consumer reporting agency or data furnisher has had the time permitted under the Fair Credit Reporting Act to conduct a reasonable investigation on the prior dispute.

The consumer reporting agency or data furnisher has returned the results of its investigation to the consumer with respect to such dispute, unless there are material changes to the information submitted with the dispute.
The credit repair organization includes with the resubmitted dispute a specific description of what information is inaccurate.

section.text: Section 408 of the Credit Repair Organizations Act (15 U.S.C. 1679f) is amended by adding at the end following:

subsection.header: Legal services within credit repair organizations
subsection.text: A credit repair organization shall be subject to this title regardless of whether the organization is, or employs, an attorney who also provides legal services to a consumer, except if such attorney is an attorney described in section 403(3)(B)(iv).

subsection.header: Credit repair organizations without a State license
subsection.text: On or after January 1, 2026, no person may act as a credit repair organization unless such person is licensed by a State.

section.header: Credit repair organization communications with furnishers of information

subsection.text: The Credit Repair Organizations Act (15 U.S.C. 1679 et seq.) is amended by inserting after section 408 the following new section:

section.header: Credit repair organization communications with furnishers of information
section.text: Disputes submitted to a person who furnishes information to a consumer reporting agency by or on behalf of a credit repair organization shall meet the following requirements:

paragraph.text: If sent by mail, the dispute shall be transmitted by first class mail and list on the envelope the—

subparagraph.text: name of the credit repair organization; and
State license number of the credit repair organization, if applicable.

paragraph.text: The dispute shall list the—

subparagraph.text: name of the credit repair organization;
State license number of the credit repair organization, if applicable; and
name of the consumer on whose behalf the dispute is submitted.

paragraph.text: In the case of any additional communication after an initial dispute, the additional communication shall clearly and conspicuously identify any material changes to the information provided in the initial written dispute and include the information described in paragraphs (1) and (2).
In the case where a credit repair organization sells or otherwise provides an online or paper blank dispute form to be completed and filed by the consumer, such form must contain the—

subparagraph.text: name and address of such credit repair organization; and
State license number of such credit repair organization, if applicable.

paragraph.text: In the case where the person responds to a dispute submitted by a credit repair organization seeking clarifying information, verifying if the customer has actually engaged with the credit repair organization, or denying the accuracy of the underlying claim, the credit repair organization shall respond in writing within 15 business days.

In the case where the credit repair organization is an attorney, the attorney shall certify that any communication is consistent with any information or documentation provided by the consumer, confirmed based upon methods or means proven to be historically reliable and accurate.

A credit repair organization, when sending a dispute, shall disclose the fact that it is a credit repair organization by placing the following disclosure on the dispute letter: This communication was submitted or prepared on behalf of the consumer by a credit repair organization, as defined in section 403 of the Credit Repair Organizations Act (15 U.S.C. 1679a).
